edu.brown.cs.systems.tracingplane.atom_layer

Interface AtomLayer<B extends BaggageAtoms>

  • Type Parameters:
    B - Some implementation of Baggage used by this transit layer.
    All Superinterfaces:
    TransitLayer<B>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    BaggageLayer<B>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericBaggageLayer, RawAtomLayer

    public interface AtomLayer<B extends BaggageAtoms>
extends TransitLayer<B>

    The AtomLayer is an implementation of the TransitLayer that specifies some default behavior for how to branch, join, and serialize Baggage. The AtomLayer provides the minimal implementation necessary for an application to participate in the tracing plane. The AtomLayer enables an application to propagate Baggage without needing to know about what data it contains or the semantics of that data.

    The AtomLayer implementation of Baggage is BaggageAtoms. A BaggageAtoms instance is a list of atoms. At atom is an arbitrary-length array of bytes. The AtomLayer makes no attempt to interpret the meaning of each atom -- this is the job of higher layers such as the BaggageLayer. Atoms are the unit of division at the AtomLayer, so they typically correspond to just one 'thing'.

    The AtomLayer specifies the following:

    • The underlying serialization format of atoms, which is to prefix the bytes of each atom with their length (encoded as a protobuf-style varint). For example, with byte[] a = new byte[10]; and byte[] b = new byte[20];, the serialized representation would be [length=32][a.length=10][ a ][b.length=20][ b ]. See AtomLayerSerialization for more information.
    • The default merge behavior when two branches of an execution join. Two Baggage instances a and b are merged by lexicographically merging their respective atoms and dropping duplicates that are encountered. respective lists of atoms while dropping duplicates as they are encountered. See Lexicographic for more information.
    • The default behavior for dropping atoms if a baggage instance is larger than permitted by a system. For example, if a system wants to keep headers less than a certain size, it might mean baggage must be less than 100 bytes in size. To trim baggage, atoms are dropped from the end of the list of atoms. If atoms are dropped, then an OVERFLOW_MARKER should be appended to the end of the list of atoms. The overflow marker is the empty atom (e.g., zero-length atom) which is lexicographically smaller than all other atoms and therefore tracks the position in the baggage where data was dropped.

    For a system to participate in the tracing plane, it must be capable of propagating at least two bytes of baggage.

    The methods in this class are similar to the methods defined by TransitLayer, with atoms(BaggageAtoms) and wrap(List) replacing TransitLayer.serialize(Baggage) and TransitLayer.deserialize(byte[], int, int).
